ELECTION OF SPEAKER
(Tribute)

3.21 p.m.

     The Leader of the House (Mr E.W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I, on behalf of all Members of this House, extend to you our congratulations on your re-election as Speaker. This is the fourth time that you have been elected to this high office and your twelfth year in the Chair.

    You, Sir, have served longer than any of your predecessors, all of whom had the advantage of training in the law. Many of the functions and a great deal of the ritual associated with your office have a judicial flavour. But you have shown that the lack of legal training has been of no disadvantage and that impartiality, even if it has to be judicial, is not a monopoly of the legal profession.

    In paying tribute to you, Sir, I must not forget your staff. The Clerk, Mr Lopez, has done yeoman's service ever since 1954. He is our last word on the Standing Orders. Your Translators are good. They have to be good in order to translate some of the speeches in this House simultaneously. Your Reporters are accurate.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, our Fifth Parliament begins today. A voice louder and stronger than mine has warned that the years, if not months, ahead may be grim. Should dark clouds gather in our sky, I would prefer to look for a silver lining. We have survived more than one crisis before and after we gained independence. During our trials and tribulations the Singaporean has proved to be resolute, resilient and resourceful. It will take more than an earthquake to bring this town to rack and ruin.

    Sir, I seek your indulgence if I appear to be too confident. But like many other Honourable Members in this House, I do not relish the thought of spending my old age on my bended knees. Hence our relentless but not desperate search for fresh talent.

    It is on that note that I have now great pleasure in welcoming our 18 new Members to this enlarged Chamber of 75. Allow me,

Column: 9

Sir, to remind them that the country and the Party are looking forward to their contributions within and will be closely watching, if not monitoring, their performances outside this House. A bit of advice from an old hand should not hurt. No Member will stray from the straight and narrow path if he always lets his conscience be his guide.

    Thank you, Sir.

     Mr Speaker: I thank the Minister for Law and Science and Technology for his very kind words about me.

    I am most grateful to the House for the great honour it has bestowed on me by relecting me to the Chair and I hope that I shall prove worthy of the confidence it has in me.

    When I was first called to the Chair a little over eleven years ago, I was overcome with awe, being deeply conscious then, as I still am now, of the responsibilities of this High Office. Happily, through the years, my task in the Chair was made easier by the warm friendship, understanding and tolerance of honourable Members and I am most grateful to the honourable Members who were in the House during those years for their cooperation. I am sure that I shall continue to receive the support of honourable Members and together we will maintain the high tradiions of this House.

    In the past, I was conscious of the enthusiasm of honourable Members to participate in debates in the House and I assure them that Members who wish to speak will not fail to catch my eye. Honourable Members will, however, appreciate that precise and relevant speeches, with touches of humour, make for effective and stimulating debates, and I took forward to presiding over many such debates.

    I wish to welcome the honourable Members who have just joined us. They would be aware that the proceedings of this House are governed by the Standing Orders so that a knowledge of the Standing Orders, no matter how superficial, would help towards a better understanding of the procedure of this House. The Clerk and his Assistants are always available for advice.

PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS


8.31 p.m.

     The President (Dr Benjamin Henry Sheares): Honourable Members, three major tasks confront Singapore in the 1980s. First, we need to build a modern industrial society

Column: 11

founded on sophisticated economic activities and a new relationship between management and labour. Second, we must get every citizen to recognise and support the pivotal role that defence and national service plays in underpinning our continued independence and prosperity. Third, we must complete the most crucial phase in the process of self-renewal, getting my younger Ministers to take the big decisions which my older Ministers have hitherto shouldered.

    Seldom have events and circumstances been more unfavourable for our economic development. Economists no longer argue whether there will be a recession in 1981. Their attention is focused on guessing how deep the recession is going to be.

    We must be prepared for slower growth and even some unemployment in the coming years. Poor economic growth will subject management-labour relationships to severe strains. Under these more difficult circumstances, management and labour will have to evolve a new relationship, one where both management and labour pull, and are seen to be pulling, together. They must never work against each other. Old habits of confrontation between management and labour must cease. Instead, there must be identity of interest among employers, management and labour so that workers as well as employers are left in no doubt that industrial disruption brings only losses for all. We must strive to cut out waste and inefficiency. Our workers must be trained, and retrained, to higher levels of skills and professionalism to prepare them for the jobs that will see us through the 1980s. To survive, we have to upgrade our economic activities.

    Since 1965, we have devoted a large part of our national resources towards building up our Armed Forces. And for good reason. They are our guarantee that Singapore will be left in peace to pursue her own ends for the good of her people. Unfortunately, we have yet to get across the message that the defence of Singapore is the responsibility of every citizen. Many people still think that, in war, the fighting will be done by the regulars and full-time national servicemen in the Singapore Armed Forces.

Column: 12



    We cannot afford a large standing army. The strength of our Armed Forces is, therefore, in our reserves. We must totally restructure our scheme of rewards and incentives. When service in the Armed Forces is accorded the respect and prestige that it deserves, then the Singapore Armed Forces will attract and retain talent in the regular service, and training and rank in the reserve service will be taken seriously. Everyone will soon realise that a citizen's rank and status as a Singapore Armed Forces reservist will affect his civilian career. We shall create a direct nexus between the advancement of a citizen as a soldier and his advancement as a civilian, and vice-versa. Our citizens must not regard the defence of Singapore as a two- or three-year affair, after which the national serviceman can put aside his uniform and leave it to others to carry on. No one will defend Singapore except Singaporeans. No one will fight for us except ourselves. This is the stark truth.

    This year marks a turning point in our process of self-renewal. The younger Ministers are taking a leading role in the political leadership and in Government. Their participation in Government decisions will become more dominant. They will evolve their own political style to keep in step with a rapidly changing electorate and the social and economic transformation that has taken place in Singapore over the last 21 years. The conduct of Government business has become more complex because our economy and our society have developed in range and in sophistication. My young Ministers bring fresh minds, bursting with enthusiasm and energy, to bear upon the problems of government. They have been trained in the new disciplines, and come up with more ambitious approaches to problem solving. My older Ministers provide that safety net of long experience and proven judgement over which the young Ministers can test out their new ideas and enthusiasm. Eventually, and not before too long, they also must acquire that touch and judgement.

    We will continue to identify and induct talent into the political leadership. There is no better way to secure our future than by

Column: 13

making sure that Singapore is served at the highest levels by her best and her brightest. We shall systematically seek out young men and women of integrity and ability who are perceptive and sensitive to the needs of the people and have the dedication and drive to work for the community. They must be men of tenacity and resolve. These are the indispensable qualities of leadership which have mobilised Singaporeans into overcoming seemingly insurmountable problems in the past.

    Singaporeans have once more shown their confidence in my Government by returning the People's Action Party in all 75 constituencies. This makes it all the more necessary to ensure that the Government does not abuse the trust built up over the last 21 years. Members of this Parliament, especially those who are not constrained by ministerial office, have a duty to voice the view of their constituents, in committees, in questions and in debates. All Bills, all legislation should be subject to the strictest scrutiny. Nothing should be passed without thorough, critical, and open debate. Parliament must mirror the views, the hopes, the doubts and the fears of Singaporeans. The more thoroughly Government policies are understood, the better the chances of successful implementation. Acceptance by and co-operation with a knowledgeable people of the policies of Government, is the way to success. This is the objective of my Government. Members will best help in achieving this objective by speaking out their views, and criticising Government policies to make them more responsive to the needs of the people.

    Singaporeans are maturing as a nation with our own lifestyles and our own aspira-

Column: 14

tions. We can learn from the West and Japan. We want their technology and knowledge, but our basic values, the essentials of our.philosophy of life, must be preserved. We cannot imitate the lifestyles or the ephemeral fancies of other peoples without doing damage to ourselves. However, we can benefit by importing from America, Europe and Japan the latest advances in medical science, computer software, the manufacturing processes for high-technology products to upgrade our economy. We can learn from Japan how to organise our society so that we become a more cohesive and a more united nation, with each Singaporean keenly aware of his responsibility to his family, to his fellow-workers, to his employer and to his country.

    Singapore has grown from a fishing village into a modern metropolis because Singaporeans believe in hard work, thrift, honesty and self-reliance. So long as we continue to practise these virtues, the future holds no fear for us.

MINISTRY OF EDUCATION


Streaming

    This review of the Ministry of Education covers the period beginning February 1979 when the new education system was introduced. Last year, streaming commenced in primary schools and this year, in secondary schools. The exercise aroused widespread public controversy, as is inevitable when a major change takes place affecting many parents and their children.

    The object of streaming pupils according to ability is to enable them to be taught at the most suitable pace. Previously, the pace of learning was set by the top 12% who made it to 'A' level in 12 years. Less able children fell by the wayside and many left school virtually illiterate. While it is easy to enunciate the objectives of streaming, it is less easy to set. up a system of implementation that will appear fair to everyone. Hence the policy of the Ministry has been to introduce streaming with caution and flexibility. Parents will accept the new policy more readily if large changes are avoided and if the reasons for the policy are clearly explained.

    In the Secondary 1 streaming this year, streaming proportions were based on the percentage of Secondary 1 pupils who would later get three 'O' level passes. Past records showed that 50% of the Secondary 1 pupils were successful. This figure was hence used to separate those who would take the 'O' level examination in four years (in the Express and Special Streams) from those who would take five years (in the Normal Stream). Parents of 3,635 children in the 40% to 49% group were given the choice of the Express or Normal Streams. 88% chose the Express stream.

    If a more stringent criterion had been used, say, five 'O' level passes, only a third would have gone to the faster streams, instead of 59%. But there could well have

Column: 16

been a public uproar. However, the purpose of streaming would have been better served and more of the lower two-thirds would have been able to get five good 'O' level passes, This would have enabled them to proceed to the Polytechnic or Ngee Ann or to the 'A' level and eventually to the University.

Curriculum Development

    The process of curriculum development comprises two main components: syllabus definition and development of materials. The Division looking after curriculum development should be the main source of innovation. The former Education Development Division in the Ministry was not suitably organised for this purpose.

    In June 1980, the Division was disbanded. The job of syllabus definition was transferred to the School Inspectorate. The production of teaching materials of all kinds was taken over by a new institute, the Curriculum Development Institute of Singapore (CDIS). The former Singapore Education Media Service (SEMS), which produced educational television (ETV) programmes and audio-visual aids, was incorporated as the Division of Educational Technology in CDIS.

    CDIS tries to attract talented, innovative and creative teachers. The Institute is sited in the Kent Ridge campus of the National University to keep it out of reach of Ministry bureaucrats. Bureaucratic procedures are reduced to the minimum. Each team of writers is led by a Project Director who is given full responsibility for his or her project. Members of CDIS who write textbooks and produce other teaching materials will receive a share of the royalties on sales.

    The Institute is concentrating on the English and Chinese Languages, Mathematics and Science, mainly for the primary level. An example is the CLIPS project which produces Chinese Language Instructional Materials for Primary Schools. This year, CLIPS materials are used in Primary 1

Column: 17

classes in 300 schools. Experts in English, Mathematics and Science from Britain and elsewhere are being engaged as consultants to the project teams. CDIS is also developing supplementary materials. Examples of these are materials for supplementary English and Chinese lessons for the Special Assistance Plan Schools and materials to correct common Singapore errors in written English. Materials for the monolingual courses and for the lower secondary science classes are also being developed. Altogether, there are 17 project teams at the moment. Teams will be formed for new projects when talented teachers have been identified.

    CDIS also conducts courses for teachers on how to use the materials it has developed. It acts as a resource centre to serve the instructional needs of teachers in schools. Its resource library containing audio-visual materials will be expanded to about five times its present size.

Moral Education

    In 1979, the Ong Teng Cheong Report reviewed the status of moral education in schools and made many recommendations for improvement. The report forms the basis of a new approach. However, little progress has been made. Implementation has proved more difficult and complex than expected.

    "Education for Living", comprising moral education and social studies, will be replaced by Moral Education as a separate subject in primary schools. A series of books entitled "Good Citizen" is being produced to inculcate in our pupils desirable moral values. Pupils will be made aware of their existence, their relationship to others, their family and ultimately the nation and the world. The values imparted at each stage will be directly related to the pupils' development and experience. Instead of the traditional didactic approach, pupils will acquire the values through discussions, story-telling and other activities. Social Studies will be introduced as an additional subject only from Primary 4.

    At the lower secondary levels, Moral Education will replace Civics. An experimental Moral Education Programme

Column: 18

developed by Dr R. Balhatchet is being tried out in Bukit Merah Secondary School and will be extended to more schools if found successful.

    Religious Education, in the form of the study of an individual religion or the comparative study of religions, is being encouraged as an 'O' level examination subject. Papers on Christianity and Islam are already available for the Cambridge General Certificate of Education 'O' Level Examination. Comparative religion will be introduced shortly by the Cambridge Examination Syndicate and the Ministry is assessing its suitability. The Ministry is also considering Hinduism and Buddhism as other options. The syllabi for these two papers have been prepared and textbooks are being prepared. However, it will take several years to produce good textbooks and teaching materials and to train teachers in their effective use. Quick results cannot be expected in this area.

Computer Training of School Pupils

    To develop a computer software industry successfully in Singapore, a projected shortfall of up to 7,800 trained computer personnel has to be met by 1990. The Ministry has started a programme of computer training for school pupils.

    In 1980, Computer Science, as an 'A' level subject, was introduced to the first batch of 50 pupils. The second batch in 1981 will have at least 400 pupils. Each junior college teaching the subject will be equipped with a mini-computer system and will have at least two teachers trained in Computer Science. Each year, 25 teachers will undergo a diploma course in Computer Science at the National University of Singapore.

    A computer appreciation course will be conducted for pupils in 17 secondary schools from January 1981. The course will arouse pupils' interest in computers and teach them to write simple computer programmes. Another 30 secondary schools will have this course from July 1981. By 1983, all secondary schools should have computer appreciation clubs as an extra-curricular activity. For this purpose, each secondary school will have a micro-computer system.

The Special Assistance Plan Schools

    The Special Assistance Plan (SAP) was introduced in 1979 in nine established secondary schools. These schools admit pupils who are within the top 10% of those who passed the Primary School Leaving Examination. Students in SAP schools sit for their GCE 'O' level examination in English. The brightest among them do English and Chinese at the first language level. Their schools provide them with a suitable environment to achieve this. Thus, the Ministry has provided SAP schools with better facilities like air-conditioned language laboratories and libraries and better staffing quota (about 12% more for SAP schools with double sessions and 30% more for those on full day). Pupils from the Chinese medium schools are given additional support in the form of an immersion programme in good English schools or a supplementary English Language programme in their own schools. A supplementary Chinese Language programme is offered to pupils from English medium primary schools.

    Pupils in the SAP schools will enjoy certain privileges. If they pass both first languages and qualify for admission to junior colleges, they will be given priority in their choice of colleges. Pupils with a grade of at least E8 in one of the two first languages and a grade of C6 in the other will be considered as having satisfied the language requirement for pre-university admission. If they obtain a grade of C6 for Chinese as First Language (CL1) at 'O' level, they will be considered to have satisfied the second language requirement for admission to the university and will be exempted from doing Chinese as Second Language (CL2) at pre-university. Pupils will also be allowed to revert to CL2 if they are unable to cope with two first languages. Pupils at the end of Secondary 3 will be allowed to sit the 'O' level CL2 paper, If they obtain a minimum CL2 grade for pre-university admission, they need not do further Chinese Language papers at 'O' level.     The medical service is a high value-added industry with economic potential. Demand in Singapore and the region for specialised medical services will increase. Progress in Clinical Work

Hospital (TTSH). This service was developed with assistance from a team of specialists in coronary by-pass surgery from Cleveland, United States, in March last year.

Health Manpower

    The quality of health service depends on the availability of good doctors and supporting personnel, especially nurses. MINISTRY OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS


    In the 1980s it will become more obvious that -our domestic political and economic developments cannot be divorced from international politics.

    Following the invasion of Kampuchea, Singapore's foreign policy has been one of concerted action with our ASEAN partners. In 1979, ASEAN countries, at the United Nations, proved their ability to mobilise a majority of world opinion to support them on this question. In 1980, we enhanced this support. In the economic field, ASEAN dialogues with our major trading partners have continued. This framework of cooperation and goodwill has been invaluable in persuading our major trading partners to liberalise their trade policies and to encourage a freer flow of investment. This regional approach has made for a more effective foreign policy than if we had acted on our own. This applies to each of the ASEAN five.

    ASEAN is taken seriously by friends and adversaries. The world is aware that ASEAN does make an impact. Even countries which had attacked ASEAN or been critical of it, like the Soviet Union and, formerly, the People's Republic of China, are varying their attitudes towards ASEAN.

    In the 1980s, Singapore and ASEAN will face problems in two areas. The global economy will suffer from the legacies of the 1970s. There will be growing unemployment in the industrialised countries where our markets lie. We must expect even more stringent measures by some of them as they act to put their and the global economy right. We, together with ASEAN, will have to ensure that our legitimate economic interests are not ignored.

    In the political field, the declared objective of communist powers remains that of inciting communist revolutions everywhere. We must expect them to persist in stirring up trouble. In Southeast Asia, the revolution will be projected through proxies. Vietnam, despite an ailing economy, still pursues its policy of militarisation, through Soviet mili-

tary aid. Today Vietnam has some 2.3 million men under arms. We should be under no illusion that this is purely for defensive purposes.

    We can meet these challenges through collective action with others who, like us, are convinced that this communist challenge can be frustrated.

    The coming decade holds many unpredictable crises. So long as we concentrate on fundamental principles to meet realities, however unpleasant, Singapore will ride through what looks like the most turbulent post-war decade.

Minister for Foreign Affairs

    The Ministry will continue to work with labour and management to increase productivity. Good work attitudes, and greater cooperation between unions, workers and management, they are the secrets to success.

Productivity

    The National Productivity Board will assist companies to automate, mechanise and computerise and to improve other areas of their management and production systems so as to raise their productivity. It will also foster greater co-operation between unions, workers and management. In this regard, it will promote Quality Control circles and other forms of management-worker co-operation. In addition it will improve its management and supervisory training programmes to help management in personnel management.     The Ministry will continue to work closely with unions and managements to promote good work attitudes. It will also take measures against bad work attitudes such as job-hopping.

    The Ministry will - closely monitor the industrial relations situation. Preventive mediation will ensure that grievances do not develop into industrial conflicts.     A tripartite committee comprising representatives from labour, management and government will be formed to ensure that workmen's compensation remains adequate. It will periodically review and recommend adjustments in the level of compensation to reflect rises in the cost of living and wages.

    Ministries and key departments will soon have full-time Public Relations Officers. The Information Division will co-ordinate the work of Public Relations Officers and improve the quality of its publications and press liaison work.

accommodation and a new hall of residence will be built.

    The Ministry of Social Affairs has traditionally concentrated on the alleviation of hardship and the rehabilitation of the disadvantaged. It will now shift its emphasis from the purely remedial to the developmental and preventive aspects of social welfare.

    In 1980 the Ministry commenced a reappraisal of its services. Services which are found not to be relevant to today's needs will be discontinued. Staff who are thus released will be enlisted to work on new services, especially in Social Research and Community Development.

The Family and the Community

    The Ministry now has a Community Development Section which is responsible for introducing new programmes designed to strengthen the family unit and to foster the evolution of a cohesive and tightly-knit society.

    A family day-care scheme was launched in October last year. This scheme enables working mothers to leave their young children in the care of carefully chosen childminders. The response to the scheme from both care-users and care-givers has been encouraging so far.

    The Community Development Section will work closely with the NTUC and voluntary organisations in the running of creches and kindergartens. Social Services

Children and Youth

    Poverty was once the main underlying cause of behavioural problems among children and youth. It no longer is. Today's delinquents are increasingly the product of a stressful home environment. Rehabilitative programmes will be modified to suit the changing character of delinquency.

    Voluntary organisations have always played a valuable role in caring for ill-treated, neglected and abandoned children. Every encouragement will be given to these organisations to raise funds and recruit staff to enable them to expand their services.

The Disabled

    The United Nations has proclaimed 1981 as the International Year of Disabled Persons. During this year, the Ministry will step up its programme of public education to instil in the minds of the public the vast potential in re-integrating disabled persons into the mainstream of life.

    Not enough has been done to train the disabled to take up gainful employment. Vocational training for the disabled, numbering about 12,000, has assumed even greater importance in the context of the shortage of unskilled and semi-skilled workers in the Republic. The Ministry will co-operate with training institutions and employers' organisations to facilitate job placement for the disabled, especially those between 15 and 45 years of age.

    The Ministry of Social Affairs and the Ministry of National Development have jointly commenced a study of how building regulations could be amended to create a barrier-free environment within public buildings so that disabled persons could move about with greater ease.

    Rehabilitative work has so far been confined to juvenile offenders.

    With effect from 1981, the Ministry of Social Affairs will undertake the rehabilitation of adult prisoners. A Prison Welfare Service will be set up under the Ministry consisting of trained rehabilitation officers. The Ministry will strive to bring the current rate of recidivism down to an acceptable level.

    The age structure of the population of Singapore will change drastically during the next 20 to 30 years. The number of persons aged 60 years or more will increase from 169,000 now to 319,000 by the close of the century. The welfare of the elderly will become a major concern of the Ministry in future.

    The Ministry has commenced a wide-ranging study of government policies which

have a bearing on the welfare of the Aged.     The Muslim community, under the leadership of the Majlis Ugama Islam Singapura (MUIS). has continued to make commendable economic and social progress.

    MUIS will assist more Muslim youths to pursue higher education in the Universities and in technical institutions. They must be equipped to play a role in a fast growing and technologically advanced economy.

    (ii) the growth of large manufacturing industries which use hazardous materials.

    The Building Control Division of the Ministry of National Development has laid down stringent fire prevention features for high-rise buildings.
